qas.question: Which species are ribbon-shaped planktonic animals?

answers.text: by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their comb-rows.
by undulating their bodies as well as by the beating of their comb-rows

qas.question: Which species moves by a darting motion?
What is another name for the Aboral?
What shape does the Aboral usually have?

plausible_answers.text: in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon

qas.question: Where is the mouth located on an Aboral?

context: <a0_0>The <a0_1><a0_2>Cestida<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> <b7_0>(<a1_2>"<a1_0><a1_1>belt animals<a1_1/><a1_0/>"<a1_2/>)<b7_0/> are <b8_0>ribbon-shaped<b8_0/> planktonic animals, with the mouth and aboral organ aligned <b9_0>in the middle of opposite edges of the ribbon<b9_0/>. There is a pair of comb-rows along each aboral edge, and tentilla emerging from a groove all along the oral edge, which stream back across most of the wing-like body surface. Cestids can swim <a2_0><a2_2>by <a2_1>undulating their bodies<a2_1/> as well as by the beating of their comb-rows<a2_2/>.<a2_0/> There are two known species, with worldwide distribution in warm, and warm-temperate waters: <a3_0><a3_1>Cestum veneris<a3_1/><a3_0/> ("Venus' girdle") is among the largest ctenophores – <a3_2><b5_0>up to 1.5 meters (4.9 ft) long<b5_0/><a3_2/>, and can <b6_0>undulate slowly or quite rapidly<b6_0/>. <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>Velamen parallelum<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, which is typically less than 20 centimeters (0.66 ft) long, can move much faster in what has been described as a "darting motion".
